Fate/Extra:Last Encore is a sequel story of the original game in a different universe.
I personally enjoyed the show quite a lot and I think studio  SHAFT handled it very nicely. Of course,there were some issues,but I generally think it was great. The appearance of our beautiful empress is something not to be missed,so enjoy the show!
The art was brilliant and I loved the fact that it was based on the original game's art style by artist Wada Arco. SHAFT's aesthetic is so unique and it's great that they brought elements from some of their previous works like Madoka Magica's nightmare fuel or the famousMonogatari series' bizarre way of portraying the characters and showing their inner state at given moments. I was quite fond of the soundtrack since it was matching to the show's intends. 


Story-wise it might be quite confusing for those that are not familiar with Fate/Extra's original game or Fate/ series in general as it proves to be newbie-unfriendly,so I highly recommend it that this isn't your starting point with the franchise. Apparently the anime adaptation is a sequel to the original game and it takes place approximately 1000 years after the events of its prequel. Due to having to cut 2 episodes off of the anime, I think some details weren't explained properly in the beginning,which could have arose some misunderstandings,but I personally don't find it to be a problem,because the proceeding of the story left a bigger impression in my mind.I find it depressing that they had to cut the anime so suddenly at episode 10 and proceed with it 3 months later,but nevertheless it was still enjoyable and deserves a better rate than the one it currently has.


I found it quite intriguing that the studio chose to concentrate mainly on Hakuno,Saber and Rin,not because the rest of the characters were redundant in the general Fate/Extra universe,but because the main trio of the adaptation were the leading point in the sequel. I actually thought that Hakuno was going to be the typical plain Fate main protagonist, but don't let this fool you! He developed splendidly throughout the story and became one of my personal favorites,although I thought of him as quite the nuisance in the beginning. What I felt lacking was the absence of some further character progression with some of the characters and therefore felt kind of rushed,but I already mentioned what the reason behind it might be.Still,they could've added an episode or so to refine it a bit. Despite that,the rest of it was fine.


Overall,I think Fate/Extra : Last Encore is something not to missed as it is purely great and a candy for the eye,despite it having a few flaws. Intriguing story,decent characters,magnificent visuals and great soundtrack are what make the whole show!Hope you enjoy the show as much as I did. I highly hope that SHAFT would be interested in either animating Fate/Extra CCC thoroughly, or just provide us with a backstory anime to Last Encore to make the image of the premise more clear.


Side note:

 I somehow regret that many dropped it too suddenly before even reaching the middle of the anime and hence caused its bad score and missed a whole bunch of content,which actually explains most of their wonders.One of  the things I found to have put the majority of people off watching it is that SHAFT didn't make it a 100% faithful adaptation to the game,even though it was intentional and the original writer of the Fate/series clearly stated in the beginning that this would be a different story,so it can bring new content to both veterans and newbies. Another reason for the lack of interest is that this Fate in particular was different from the rest in terms of art,story,setting and way of conveying the information,which I don't view as negative,but instead as a nice moment of diversity. I don't see the need for each Fate to be the same as the other and I'm tired of this stereotype regarding the franchise that it should be mandatory for it to contain "epic battle scenes" or be animated by ufotable, because the charm of each series would vanish if that were to happen.

In terms of the fate series, this is pretty moderate, sure there's better, sure there's worse. Another male historical icon has been converted to, ahem, ~a woman~, which if you watch any of the fate series and are complaining about this fact, you sir are watching the wrong kind of medium. And if you wanted more Tohsaka, you'll definitely be satisfied, because she's relevant for the plot, but if you are just here for Tohsaka, and we know some of you will be here for those juicy thighs, you will probably just want to look up more fan art of her. Fate/extra last encore islike the mashed potatoes of the fate series, it's something good to eat anytime, but it's not special enough to stand out on its own.

I will keep this brief. This is shaft we are talking about. The monogatari vibes are insane. But because it is shaft, the show has a lot of... complicated scenes. Rapid jump cuts, evocative angles that are suppose to carry the emotion instead the dialogue. But debatable this is a harder to follow anime than monogatari. The monogatari series has a lot of quick shots of statements to help illustrate thoughts. That aside, again because it is studio Shaft, the animation is superb, the characters can look vibrant, or menacing when needed. If you can follow the story direction, it is a great story. Astory showing multiple viewpoints of how to make the best of a bad situation, or to make nothing of it at all. But given this is marketed for everyone, I marked down the story and character because the sort of way of presenting the story can lead to confusion. overall I liked the show fine. It is another fate series well done, but if you came here expecting something more like Ufotable's works and nothing different, you WILL be disappointed.

I love the Fate/ Series. Even when a given show or game has been bad, I've usually been able to find an objectively redeeming part to it that I can say made the experience worthwhile. Unfortunately, Fate/Extra: Last Encore didn't really have anything like that. If you look at the art, in still frames it could look quite captivating, but when you watch the animation, you can see so many cut corners and lost opportunities. If you listen to the music, it was okay... but that's it. It didn't feel like it was tailored to the show like the music in other Fate/ series did.The story was preachy and repetitive with too much of an attempt at being philosophical, but without the quality to back it up. At least Unlimited Blade Works and Apocrypha were able to push their philosophies without needing to tell you every episode or two what they were trying to get across; those shows would show you what they wanted to say more often than tell you, but Last Encore is too focused on telling you "this is the theme", likely due to the fact there are only 10 Episodes so far. When the second cour/season of it comes out (Fate/Extra: Last Encore - Irusterias Tendouron), I hope the writers start using less verbal statements about the theme and instead allow the artists and animators to give more visual cues. Speaking of the art, while I commented on the overall appearance earlier, WHEN the show used artistic symbolism, as seldom as it did, it was often done to great effect. I wish to see more of that going forward, but so far have no reason to expect such. Finally... the Characters.


Our protagonist is bland. Shirou and Sieg at least had core traits going for them and Sieg was about as blank of a slate you could get before creating a brain-dead character. Hakuno, however, has no personality, no motive, and no desires... you know, aside from "I want to kill because I am angry at everyone who is alive for no reason other than the fact they are alive." I can understand in the first couple of episodes that he wasn't sure who he wanted to be or what he wanted to do, but after 10 episodes? He has reached the point where he needed to get some sort of will of his own. He's supposed to be the "hero", but really the protagonist keeping everything moving has been Saber.

Saber, our obligatory genderbent knight-king, is probably the most well-done character in this show, and this is coming from someone who hates all the Artoria clones the franchise has made and is irrationally in love with Tosaka Rin. Saber has a wish and a reason to fight. She leads the plot forward and has very real desires and flaws. She is the closest we get to a fully-developed character... but if you look at her, she's really not that well fleshed-out. Like everything else about the show, her character is very much told, and very rarely shown. She is often explained in interesting ways, such as the clip show about her true name, which happened to be one of the best writing moments in the show... yet when we hear about her, it's only in info dumps. When we see who she is, it's in only two lights. Light 1: She is a fighter constantly willing to rush head-first into a struggle if it means furthering her goals. Light 2: She is a child who wants what she wants and will not accept what anybody else has to say about the matter. You can see the overlap and the laziness thereof. She has interesting moments, but they don't warrant her being given the same love as other beloved female characters within the franchise's animes.

Tosaka Rin, a character who can only be messed up by someone who has little writing experience, is probably one of the most bland characters in the show right after the main character himself. She doesn't do anything aside from set in motion a scheme that she doesn't do anything about for the majority of the episodes and when she does "do something", the extent of her action is saying, basically, "go through this door and get to the center area where you'll have to make a tough decision because neither me nor Rani could do what we were supposed to."

Rani, the second most interesting character: She is literally there to help explain Rin's actions/inaction (depending on how you look at it). She's interesting solely because they don't tell you everything you want to know about her right away, and they give you some mystery befitting her attempt at a personality. I repeat, I love Rin as my favorite girl in the franchise. With my bias towards Rin, this flat 2-dimensional character should not be more likable and interesting than the character I went into this show already prepared to adore... but she is. It just shows how poorly characters were handled. Rani did have the potential to be a great character, just as all the characters in this did, but those involved in this project were either too inexperienced or too disinterested to get this show done right.


Still, despite all my objections with the show, it's not a "bad" show. It's not good by any stretch, but it's definitely an entertaining show if you can look past its many, MANY flaws, much like Sword Art Online in that respect. I enjoyed this show far more than I should have, but that's mostly because Saber, Rani, and a side character named Hakuno (not the main character) all pulled their weight in making the show palatable. Sure, I wish it was better executed and see no reason why it was done as sloppily as it was, but it just goes to show UFOtable is better equipped for this franchise than Shaft is, which is a disappointment, but not totally unexpected.

Yet another entry of the evergrowing list of anime from the fate franchise, I was finally able to watch it on netflix just a few days ago. If you are completely new to the Fate series then be aware that there are things within this show that you'll have to piece together in order to understand. As for Fate fans, this show will be pretty enjoyable. I would recommend Fate/Extra: Last Encore to people already familiar with Fate. 
The story is pretty decent, although it is pretty obvious that it is based off a videogame given how linear it is. What I mean by this is that each encounter with a servant and master all follow the same structure with there being only one master on each floor that the main characters have to beat in order to move on to the next floor, just like in a video game where you need to beat the boss in order to move on to the next level. This structure isn't necessarily bad but it does give the show a somewhat predictable course as it doesn't really diversify all that much. However, the story is rather still enjoyable. The main issue with the story though is just how confusing it can be, even to people already familiar with fate. There isn't enough explanation for things, even with all the exposition given. There were times while watching where I stopped to go look at the type-moon wiki just to clarify the details of the story. Even then, I'm still unsure about some parts of it. So be aware that you'll need to pay attention to the details given and be prepared to be confused. Another issue is just how easily some of the servants are defeated, not once did I feel like the main characters were going to lose or were going to suffer any major consequence. 


 The art and animation of this show is great, which is no surprise given how this is made by Studio Shaft.  The vibrant colors and the slight shading give this show a crisp aesthetic, making it a very good source of eye candy.


 The soundtrack is just fine, it doesn't really stand out and isn't very memorable. That isn't to say it's terrible, it's enjoyable to listen to whenever it plays. My favorite song from the show is definitely the ending song, which is augmented by beautiful visuals.


The characters of this show are what redeems it the most, a good portion of them are at least okay. If the story is going to be structured in a linear way then having good characters on each floor would be essential to whether or not that structure would work and fortunately is does manage. The characters that aren't very developed much are Rin Tohsaka and Rani, who are given the least amount of characterization out of them all. Rin mainly serves as a source of exposition and aids Hakuno and Saber a little bit but that's really it. She maintains her personality from Fate/Stay Night but that isn't very apparent given her lack of development. Nani is worse off since she is pretty emotionless and almost nothing is revealed about her character at all. Go to the type-moon wiki and you'll see how she really is a fleshed-out character but I guess that didn't carry over into the anime which is unfortunate. Another poor character is Rider as not much is revealed about her other than her having a pirate-like personality. All the other characters show at least some personality and conflict. A good example is surprisingly Shinji Matou, the most unlikable character from Fate/Stay Night, who manages to come off as sympathetic. He doesn't like having to kill people in the Moon Holy Grail War and wants to live peacefully but is also pretty arrogant. Moving on, the main character Hakuno is just okay. He's kind of bland to be honest but this is mended by his conflict regarding what he is and how he views himself and the world around him for it. He tries to deny what he is initially but eventually decides to not allow that to define him. The main problem with him is his constant pondering regarding who he is which feels cliche very typical with Fate and the anime gives little reason for us to care about this question or him for that matter. However, the character that makes this anime for me is Saber. It seems like no matter how mediocre any fate anime can be, the Sabers from those shows are always great and Fate/Extra's Saber is no exception. She is very open, accepting yet prideful and flamboyant. She has the grace of Saber from Fate/Zero and Stay Night and the charm and charisma of Rider from Fate/Zero. I think anyone who watches this show will find it difficult not to like her. Her only issue is just how overpowered she is which diminishes the tension of the story, but it's still great to watch her character as she is given the most development. 


  Overall, this show is flawed yet still enjoyable, especially for anyone who's a fan of Fate. I'd recommend this to people already familiar with Fate; to those who haven't watching anything from Fate, don't start here.

"Fate extra last encore is made so it can be viewed by newcomers and old fans alike" - says the lying mushroom.
So Nasu lied again, in other words bears still shit in the woods. This is the guy who said that the tsukihime remake is still undergoing while playing bloodborne while getting others to write for him. Nasu's word hold as much weight as toilet paper, and you can use it as such. But there is a more important issue we need to tackle, and that is why does this exist?
As a long term fate franchise viewer, I am up to date with the mostrecent patches and nerfs of the franchise. So I have a question, why make another alternate timeline for FE, especially when it is obviously getting pruned?


Yes, FELE is a pruning event, 990 years in the future, humanity near extinct, hakunon lost to twice. For all extent and purpose, this is a pruning event. You aren't going to continue this timeline, TM, and you know it.


The official timeline is, FE -> CCC -> extella (roughly, even though they technically are still separate timelines), FELE fits none of these. Hell Twice is nicknamed 2030, not 3020.


So, the anime in addition to being impossible to understand for newcomers, it is also fanfic for FE. It reuses everything from FE, and brings nothing new.


Why, WHY DON'T YOU JUST ANIMATE FE then? or Extella/zero (ie. FE under a different name)


WHY, what is the purpose of this show!?


I have no problem with TM reusing old characters and setting, FGO CCC event did that, but hey at least CCC event still provided some new lore and setting, it is not 100% reliant on CCC (maybe 80%), or when rasputin dug up Kirei's corpse, at least we got rasputin from that, and rasputin interaction was new.


What is FELE bringing? nothing. You can't watch this without knowing deeply about FE, but if you know FE, why watch this show instead of the actual continuation of the timeline?


In short, official TM fanfic (as canon as carnival phantasm), no need to watch, just go play FE.

At the time of writing this review, there is a trailer making the rounds online for the upcoming film Christopher Robin in which a CG Winnie the Pooh talks to Ewan McGregor in the instantly recognisable voice of Jim Cummings. To hear this voice, which has become so ubiquitous through Disney as to be permanently associated with the character, coming from the mouth of a CG teddy bear in live action is both deeply nostalgic and unspeakably confusing. The effects of seeing the Fate franchise moved into SHAFTland are not quite so dramatic, but comparably bizarre.
SHAFT are a studio of limited gifts. Their works are instantly recognisable,and although their style is undoubtedly their own, it teeters on the verge of predictability after seeing two or three anime filled with the same abstract imagery and sharp colours; meandering monologues and jarring close-ups; shiny-skinned and scantily-clad girls; characters who tilt their heads back; and the myriad other tells that alert informed viewers that they are watching another SHAFT production. Whilst this is an unmistakable asset to an anime whose themes and characters accord with the SHAFTian style, such as Puella Magi Madoka Magica, it is liable to distract and irritate in other circumstances.


Thankfully, the opaque chuunibyou babble that characterises all of Kinoko Nasu's artistic output dovetails nicely with SHAFT's predilection for directionless talking head monologues delivered either in ironic deadpan or with ironic pep. This lends a certain lightness to Fate/EXTRA Last Encore's inevitable rhapsodic elaborations upon the, uh, Moon Cell (?), which by ufotable's trusty and exquisitely detailed pen may have been treated with grim earnestness. Wait, is this a good thing?


Perhaps it doesn't matter. Despite an excruciatingly SHAFTian first episode in which protagonist Hakuno Kishinami is introduced as a student in an virtual reality institution apparently modelled off Madoka Kaname's middle school—an identical glass-walled design is used in both anime, so we can only assume the programmers were big Madoka fans—Fate/EXTRA Last Encore turns out to be at least as entertaining as the Monogatari series and less time-consuming. Much of this entertainment is admittedly thanks to the gender-swapped Nero Claudius, who is as likeable a Saberface as Type-Moon have created; apparently written under the reasonable assumption that nothing Fate-related will sell without an Artoria clone attached, Fate/EXTRA Last Encore truly goes the distance in its reliance upon its ostentatious and proud heroine to carry the anime on charisma alone.


Can SHAFT be blamed for their emphasis on Nero? Given the willingness of masochists worldwide to endure endless Monogatari iterations on the promise of more Senjougahara content, the allure of a charismatic female babbler appears to be a winning strategy for the studio. It is undeniable: the quality of Fate/EXTRA Last Encore is directly proportional to the screen-time and dialogue allotted to Nero, hence the nigh unwatchable first episode in which she is absent. She preens, she proclaims, she proselytises. She says 'umu!', which is attractively declarative. She has gigantic breasts and knee-high golden armoured boots with stupendous heels.


Umu! This anime has characters. Besides Nero! It has characters. A few of them are even familiar to us. Rin Tohsaka plays a supporting role as an amateur thigh boots model. I am sure this role will prove satisfactory to Tohsaka's ravenous enthusiast community, which perdures as resolutely as Saber's. We also have small appearances by Shinji and Sakura Matou‚ the former of whom is as characteristically unsympathetic as his ordinary iteration, but with added head tilt. The rest of the cast is composed of new characters, including the requisite heroic spirits. SHAFT takes advantage of the freedom that the virtual reality setting provides by using the environment occupied by the spirit as part of their set piece e.g. Robin Hood appears in a forest area.


These new characters inflate the cast, but unlike earlier Fate adaptations like Fate/Zero and Fate/Apocrypha, the focus of Fate/EXTRA Last Encore is quite narrowly on our protagonists, forgoing a broader view of all the Holy Grail War participants. Whereas those anime conveyed the impression that the various combatants were in equal danger, with no overwhelming preference shown towards any character, Hakuno and Nero's enemies are predominantly presented as antagonists, and they receive limited characterisation before being dispatched. On the one hand, this makes the show more predictable; but it also proves more economical given the episode count of ten, and it's hard to argue with this approach when Nero is clearly the central driver of the plot, urging the unmotivated Hakuno to continue his fight.


Umu! This anime has a plot. Besides Nero! It has a plot. After unexpectedly summoning UmU, Hakuno discovers that he is the first Master to contract a Servant in this ambivalently apocalyptic virtual reality future world for a thousand years; however, he has lost his memory of everything before his last moments at school, making him effectively a brainless magic meat puppet. With little else to do besides study Nero's breasts in the VR thermae (unintentionally satirising the otaku lifestyle more ferociously than any of those tired light novel adaptations with otaku protagonists), he successively traverses the computer generated environments of the moon machine reality's 'strata', including a city, a forest and a ghostly dreamland. On each stratum, he engages in the standard combat between Masters that is the hallmark of Fate. As such, the other Masters are fought in a discrete and consecutive fashion rather than in a free-for-all.


Umu! So far so simple. The computer generated nature of these strata is actually the point we should emphasise, because it permits SHAFT to express their incomprehensible visual style to its most fully abstract expression in sharp congruity with the comparably incomprehensible dialogue. Altogether, this produces a mental effect unprecedented in anime history or phenomenology, which I would metaphorically describe as the gradual transformation of the brain into fluffy fresh cotton candy. I touched the Swirl of the Root and, unable to handle the truth of the universe, I ceased to exist as a continuous consciousness. I have rejoined the Akashic Records and my physical shell hosts but sugary sweet pink happy fluff created by my vestigial organs as a hopeless immune response to the mental onslaught of Fate/EXTRA Last Encore.


Umu! Okay, I am back. I cannot tell if Fate/EXTRA Last Encore is a good anime. I believe I enjoy it unironically on the basis that it was probably produced ironically; but because I cannot verify this, I also harbour a suspicion that I may be inappropriately enjoying an autistic man's severely disturbed attempt to contrive 'human drama'. Actually, on second thought, this describes at least 30% of my experiences with any media involving Type-Moon and SHAFT individually, so it follows that overlap between the two would produce this outcome. There is no possibility of escape: this anime must be accepted.


Umu! Let's begin again: I cannot tell if Fate/EXTRA Last Encore is an anime that expresses a capacity to be enjoyed by a wide audience, but it will probably be appreciated by anybody who actually wants to watch it. Yorokobe, shounen.

This anime is not the best fate anime and it isn't the worst either. It's just a boring anime. Let me give you a background of myself before you start judging. I have watched all the fate anime, play fgo, read the visual novels, and even played fate extra. That still didn't make me biased enough to blindly like this anime. Let me get the good points out of the way because it's only the art and the sound. 
The art was amazing and I could tell who did it as soon as I saw the characters move. The guy from bakemonogatari. The mannerisms ofhis character and the backgrounds of his scenes are so distinct that I could tell they the people that had a part in bakemonogatari also had a part in this anime. That turned out to be one of the one problems even though I was initially excited, but I'll get into that later.


The sound was pretty good. I honestly have no qualms about the sound track at all. It was appropriate for the scenes and nothing seemed out of place. I even added a few songs to my playlist, including the op and ed.


Ok now we can talk about the bad stuff.So I watched three anime this season. They were Overlord,Fate Extra Last Encore , and Darling in the Franxx which is still going on. This was the worst out of the three. Why you ask? The show was boring. The first episode had me hyped up for the rest of the season and I could tell that they took some artistic liberties, but I was ok with that. The anime is not fateful to the game. It is not a problem I am just stating a fact. Just because the anime and the game have the same characters does not mean that the anime is fateful to the game. Hell they even changed some of the character dynamics between a master and servant. So it is safe to say that the anime wanted to be its own thing and wanted to distance itself from the game. Which I can kind of understand because the game feels like a visual novel with nothing but dialogue.  Ok, so I can see that I am on a rant so I will try to consolidate the problems into two major problems. These two major problems being pacing and character development.


So let us start off with pacing. You remember how I said that it was a bad that the people that worked on bakemonogatari, also worked on this? Well this is why. The pacing was god awful. So this is the structure of the anime. Frist episode introudtion, 2-3 Frist Servant, 4-5, Second Servant, 6-7, Third Servant, 8-9 Fourth Servant,  and 10 episode is conclusion. Now this structure doesn't seem bad and you know considering what they were working with, it seems like the best way to do it. But you want to know why the first episode was the best out of the series? It had the best blend of action and dialogue. After that it's just philosophical dialogue for like 18 minutes and then action for like 1.  If you have seen bakemonogatari then you know what I'm talking about. They could turn a discussion about drinking water into a 5 minute philosophical discussion. Now that works in bakemonogatari, but not in fate. They throw in some exposition here and there, but most of the time I'm just zoning out. The fight scenes were good, but they ended so quickly that the 1 1/2 episode build up to it wasn't even worth it. The next problem is the character development.


Now I will start off by saying I like Nero. I think she is cute and better than Saber. But I flipped a table when I saw that umu counter. I have no idea why the translators did that,but it honestly pissed me off seeing that umu counter in the uppper left counter. I will admit that the one episode they had for Nero's character development was fine. It wasn't the best, but it was the best part of episode that it appeared in. So over the course of the anime, Nero does not develop because she's basically a completed character. So who do we look to for character development? The main character Hakuno. In the game Hakuno is a self insert character. You pick his choices and his name, so he's a blank slate. They could have done anything with his character and no one would have batted an eye, but they didn't. I would dare say that he is the worst protagonist in the entire fate series. I hate Shriou and Sieg, but he is the worst. Does he actually change as a character? Yes, but it's near the very end of the anime. See the problem with the development is that he has discussions with Nero and through these discussions and battles, he grows as a character. But for some reason, he still seems like the same character as when he started. I honestly don't know they did that. He clearly states his motives and becomes determined, but he still seems like an underdeveloped character. Fooly Cooly an anime with only 6 episodes, I repeat 6 EPISODES did better with character development than this anime. I think the main problem is that character is being dragged by the plot and he only ever makes 2 real choices in the entire anime without the input from others.


So why did I mention Overlord 2 and Darling in the Franxx? Darling in the Franxx started off as a meme for me, but 13 episodes in and I'm still engaged because of how good the characters are. Hell even the character in that anime has inner monologues, but there only a few seconds and now 90% of the episode. Overlord 2 has mostly action, but once again that setting and story are so interesting that I never felt bored watching it. Well I read the books as well  so there is a little bias.


Should they have followed the source material? Yes and no. They should have followed the format and setting of the game. Fill in the grinding with whatever they want. Would that have made the anime better? I don't know, it depends on their execution.  Some of the changes like the character dynamics I liked, but some changes made no sense or had no bearing on the plot at all. So it made we wonder why they made those changes if they never did anything with them.


Once again the anime is not bad nor is it good. Fate apocrypha was so bad that I stopped at episode 23. But it was still better than this anime in almost every way, except for the sound and art. 


P.S: Sorry for bad grammar and lack of focus.

I've only watched 5 episodes but this is what I've gathered thus far. 
If you've played the Fate Extra games, then... don't expect that. The characters and the designs are from the first Extra but the setting is an AU. Although it also seems as though the Moon Cell Holy Grail War may have occurred before the setting of this anime. So get ready to be introduced to a different virtual reality, some kind of restart? I'm not 100% sure yet. 
Also, I would like to add that Saber (Nero) uses Imperial Privilege which is a skill that she has in FGO (and I donot believe she has that skill in the game).\n\n
What I love about this series so far are the characters. Nero especially. Nero has this charisma about her which shines in the animation. I actually played Fate Extella recently and I had mixed feelings about her in that game, but I'm loving her in this. Shinji isn't too bad in this either. And Twice looks so good. \n\n
It's hard to form any real opinions with 5 episodes, but I'm enjoying it thus far and will recommend this to other Fate fans. I think it'll be good for non-Fate fans as well, as the setting is different than the main plotline.

***THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS***
You thought Apocrypha was bad? You thought Sieg was a bland character? You thought Apocrypha's story wasn't interesting? You thought Darnic and Vlat Tepes were pointless? Well, Fate/Extra: Last Encore is here to set a new standard.
The premise is completely different from your standard Fate stuff. Our story, or lack thereof, is set in a virtual world where a super computer chooses 128 masters who are pitted against each other in order to ascend and reach the 7th stratum, whatever the hell that is. Our hero,
Hakuno Kishinami, after somehow surviving multiple knife stabs in the back, gets chosen as a 129th masterand alongside his servant Saber fights the other masters and their servants. 


Well, if by fight you mean that Saber effortlessly slashes the enemy with her sword, then the previous sentence is spot on. There was absolutely no creativity in the fights. Not even a minimal amount of strategy and tactics. No enemy felt strong. There was no sense of struggle, difficulty or danger. In one occasion Saber just gets a power-up from Hakuno's command spell and was again able to defeat her enemy with ease. Not to mention that the command spell mechanic was never explained. The world building was atrocious. New terms and mechanics were often being introduced on the spot without a detailed explanation just so a current problem could be solved or an enemy defeated (codecast, dead face etc). This anime just throws terms left and right, like S.E.R.A.P.H, Moon Cell, Angelica Cage etc. without thoroughly explaining them and/or establishing a logical connection. Somewhere at episode 6 I stopped trying to make any sense of the story and just continued watching to see how much of a disaster this anime was gonna turn out.


The battle royale element, something which is a primary aspect of Fate, is completely eliminated. There are no pacts and ceasefires, no multiple Masters and Servants engaging in combat at the same time, no lone Servant forming a contract with a new Master. Absolutely no dynamic in the conflict and relations between Master and Servant. It's just Hakuno and Saber versus everyone else and it all comes down to this: Hakuno and the almighty Saber ascend to a new stratum, defeat a Master and a Servant, ascend to the next stratum,

rinse and repeat. Completely boring if you ask me. For some reason, they skipped the 4th stratum. I guess even the staff found the idea boring and repetitive or they ran out of money.


No character had any major development and I didn't really care for any of them. Saber was the closest one to getting actual development but even hers was a poor attempt at a backstory. Hakuno is worse than Sieg and the only thing for which I remember him are his constant "All right", "I understand", "Thank you" replies and his blank stare which is seen maybe about 30 or more times throughout the anime all thanks to bad directing and pointless still shots.


The character interactions were lame and the dialogue was really badly written. Sometimes, the anime takes a simple thing and tries to turn it into a major achievement. Take for example episode 4. It was obvious the sniper fire was coming from the tower, which was the tallest and the only structure in the forest and it's an obvious fact that snipers prefer high places. But in a later scene, Saber praises Hakuno because he was able to quickly determine the sniper's position. Lolwut? *clap clap clap*


The animation was nothing special, but certain segments were so bad that I actually had to pause the video in order to laugh at how bad they were. For example, in episode 2 during the bath scene, when Saber does a back flip it all looks like some kind of noobish flash animation. In one shot there's just a black silhouette of Saber moving horizontally from right to left and in the next shot we see Saber's cardboard cutout turning counter-clockwise until finally she lands on her feet (the only part which was done right). The whole thing however looked really cheap and stupid. Second example would be in episode 5 when Rani gets shot and Hakuno falls off her bike and rolls on the ground. That looked pretty lame.  The same walking animation was used on several scenes and very often, when characters jumped or were falling from a great height, they looked like some static sprites in a video game animation. How did Shaft go from Madoka to this? I guess 7 years is a really long time.


I didn't like the visual designs either. There were even worse than Ufotable's, which are in my opinion worse than the original DEEN's, which tried to be as closest to the VN designs as possible. As if Hakuno's poker face wasn't enough, I also got to see an ugly version of Rin, Sakura and Shinji.


There was a lot of fanservice. Even the OP has a panty shot. In the anime, whenever Saber isn't saying "umu", she's probably one-shotting an enemy or flashing her butt and boobs. I gotta say, those are some good milkers but I wish the milking stopped at Fate/Apocrypha.


The soundtrack is generic and boring. And the worst part is that it often switches from orchestral music to some kind of electronic, drumstep mishmash with wub wubs and saw synths. I guess that would make sense since the setting takes place in a virtual world but in

the end it all sounded very stupid and a bit cringey. The OP is actually good, in my opinion. Maybe because I am fond of rock and metal. I didn't like the ED.


Fate/Extra: Last Encore was very bad. The story was a mess of different concepts put together without any explanation or connection. Nothing seemed logical and every concept felt like it was created on the spot to solve the current situation and then immediately be discarded. The characters were boring and were killed off rather quick. The fights were lame, the animation was weak and the soundtrack inconsistent. So why did I give it a 2/10 rating. Well, the OP was good.

Thoughts on Fate/Extra Last Encore:
It was by far and a way the worst Fate franchise anime series ever made. Firstly: the story. It's difficult to try to summarise the show without spoiling huge details but it starts off with the protagonist (named Hakuno) who feels only hatred and has no memories of his past. He lives in a digital world that is somehow on the moon, and in episode 1 he gets stabbed and nearly murdered by Shinji Matou from the main series during a school murder-contest to see which students will get to participate in the next Holy Grail War, surviving long enough tofind the sword of Nero Saber, whom he summons to fight for him after a sudden thousand-year timeskip. Hakuno and Nero have to fight various masters and servants in order to make their way to the Holy Grail.

The series has countless major flaws which made it almost impossible to enjoy. Firstly, the protagonist himself is extremely boring. He claims to only feel hatred for all those around him (and this is further reinforced by the plot twist regarding his identity), but his actions never support this and instead he just acts like a normal guy all the time. None of his internalised conflict ever shows itself, and this makes all of his monologues sound like pretentious nonsense.

This is worsened by the fact that the story is filled with weird flashbacks, memories, and hallucination scenes which make it extremely hard to follow. Rin Tohsaka (she's in this series too) has a tendency to disappear for an episode or two at a time without explanation, then reappear once again without explanation. Speaking of without explanation, Rin in this series wields Gae Bolg and has an extremely Scathach-like costume, but we never learn why or how she came to be infused with Scthach's appearance or weapon. What they do with her in the final episode also makes no sense, since Rin and Rani's conflict could apparently have easily been avoided if Rin had just done what she did for Hakuno before a certain too-spoilery-to-talk-about event happened. It is also never explained how Alice knew about the monster at the end of her sanctum when it didn't exist until [spoiler] turned into it.

Needless to say, plotholes are rife throughout the show, though I will admit that a lot of them probably come from the fact that the show has such a short episode count, so writer Kinoko Nasu had to cram as much story as he could into a very short time, and in so doing cut major corners.

The only truly great episodes in the series are the ones featuring Alice (Nursery Rhyme), but I admit that I mainly love those so much becasue of the stunning experimental animation styles used.

Regarding the rest of the animation, the show is a mixed bag. The 2D work is flat-up astonishing, but it's often superimposed with terrible, cheap-looking CGI that ruins the visual aesthetic.

Another problem is how a large number of the enemy servants are built up to look like major threats in the trailer and at the start of their arcs, only to be easily defeated anticlimactically by Saber every single time with no real variation. The battles themselves often feel like they waste a lot of potentially amazing weapons, such as the entire fleet of ghost ships that Francis Drake's noble phantasm summons, all of which do basically nothing and are never utilised during the aerial battle.


It really did feel like a lot of "cool factor" was missing due to the lack of other masters and servants throughout the Moon Cell Sanctums aside from the floor masters and Hakuno as well, since all of the fights were either one-on one or two-on-two with very little in the way of interference or unexpected developments, and most of them felt underwhelming as a result when compared to the epic scale of the battles in the recent Fate/Apocrypha.


In summary then, Fate/Extra Last Encore is a boring, pretentious, VERY confusing, plot-hole filled show with terrible characterisation, a lead who is overpowered to the point of destroying tension, and some of the most underwhelming battles I have ever seen in anime. 3/10, not recommended (apart from the Nursery Rhyme arc).
